definitions.definition: Any of several types of pronged ( tined ) tools (physical tools), as follows:

subdefinitions.definition: A utensil with spikes used to put solid food into the mouth , or to hold food down while cutting.

Any of several types of pronged tools for use on farms , in fields , or in the garden or lawn , such as a smaller hand fork for weeding or a larger one for turning over the soil . Such a pronged tool having a long straight handle, generally for two-handed use, as used for digging , lifting , mucking , pitching , etc.

definitions.definition: ( by abstraction, from the tool shape ) A fork in the road , as follows:

subdefinitions.definition: ( physical ) An intersection in a road or path where one road is split into two .

definitions.definition: ( by abstraction , from the tool shape ) A point where a waterway , such as a river or other stream , splits and flows into two (or more) different directions.
( metonymic , analogous to any prong of a pronged tool ) One of the parts into which anything is furcated or divided; a prong; a branch of a stream, a road, etc.; a barbed point, as of an arrow.
examples: this fork of the river dries up during droughts

definitions.definition: ( figuratively , decision-making ) A point in time where one has to make a decision between two life paths.

subdefinitions.definition: ( metonymic ) Either of the (figurative) paths thus taken.

definitions.definition: ( figuratively , by abstraction, from a physical fork ) ( software development, content management, data management ) A departure from having a single source of truth (SSOT), sometimes intentionally but usually unintentionally.

subdefinitions.definition: ( metonymic ) Any of the pieces/versions (of software , content , or data sets ) thus created.

( software ) The launch of one or more separate software development efforts based upon a modified copy of an existing project , especially in free and open-source software . ( software ) Any of the software projects resulting from the launch of such separate software development efforts based upon a copy of the original project.
examples: LibreOffice is a fork of OpenOffice.

subdefinitions.definition: ( content management ) The splitting of the coverage of a topic (within a corpus of content) into two or more pieces. ( content management ) Any of the pieces/versions of content thus created.
examples: A content fork may be intentional (as from a schism about goals) or unintentional (merely from a lack of reorganizing, so far).

subdefinitions.definition: ( cryptocurrencies ) A split in a blockchain resulting from protocol disagreements, or a branch of the blockchain resulting from such a split.

definitions.definition: ( chess ) The simultaneous attack of two adversary pieces with one single attacking piece (especially a knight).
( British , vulgar ) The crotch . (Can we add an example for this sense?)

examples: Are you qualified to drive a fork ?

definitions.definition: Either of the blades of a forklift (or, in plural, the set of blades), on which the goods to be raised are loaded.
examples: Get those forks tilted back more or you're gonna lose that pallet!

definitions.definition: ( cycling , motorcycling , by abstraction from a pronged tool's shape ) In a bicycle or motorcycle , the portion of the frameset holding the front wheel, allowing the rider to steer and balance, also called front fork .
examples: The fork can be equipped with a suspension on mountain bikes.

definitions.definition: The upper front brow of a saddle bow , connected in the tree by the two saddle bars to the cantle on the other end.

definitions.definition: The bottom of a sump into which the water of a mine drains.

main_definition: ( mining ) The bottom of a sump into which the water of a mine drains.
